Award.AbstractNarration: The Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) will help understand dark energy by mapping out the distribution of matter throughout the Universe. One of the greatest mysteries in science is that the expansion of the Universe is currently accelerating, implying that a mysterious dark energy permeates the Universe and pushes on it. The discovery of dark energy resulted in a Nobel Prize, but its nature is no clearer today than it was 20 years ago. In fact, more recent measurements have led to less certainty, with different measurements of exactly how fast the Universe is expanding. CHIME is a new radio telescope designed to measure distant galaxies through the radio emission of neutral hydrogen gas that resides within them. In order to measure the hydrogen emission, other bright radio signals from our own galaxy and other sources must be removed. This foreground removal requires a precise understanding of the CHIME instrument itself. This project will measure the instrument, improve nuisance radio emission removal, and combine the CHIME measurements with galaxy catalogues to make a measurement of dark energy. The program will also develop education-oriented radio receivers that will be used in STEM programs at MIT, WVU and Yale. Radio receivers for education have been developed through a partnership between WVU and the Green Bank Observatory to teach teachers the digital signal processing techniques necessary to build a digital spectrometer.<br/><br/>Analysis will be undertaken that cross-correlates 21cm maps from CHIME with optical galaxy survey data from eBOSS to measure the large-scale structure (LSS) of the Universe. CHIME is designed to measure neutral hydrogen associated with galaxies at redshifts from 0.8 to 2.5, producing constraints on dark energy over a critical redshift range that is difficult to probe statistically with optical galaxy surveys alone. To make this measurement bright foreground emission from our own galaxy and extragalactic sources must be removed, which places stringent requirements on instrument calibration. In this program the researchers will attempt to measure the expansion history through: (i) improved instrument beam modelling, (ii) demonstrated foreground removal techniques, and (iii) the measurement of large-scale structure with 21cm emission in cross-correlation with eBOSS optical galaxies.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The collaborative research initiative, "Cosmology with CHIME," sought to use the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) to map the large-scale distribution of matter in the Universe on scales much larger than galaxies. CHIME is a novel, digitally-driven radio telescope capable of mapping the sky with unprecedented speed.

At the heart of our investigation was the objective to cross-correlate CHIME's maps of the radio sky - which are sensitive to the density of hydrogen gas - with the locations of galaxies as cataloged by the eBOSS optical galaxy survey. Any cross-correlation signal is indicative that hydrogen and galaxies are distributed amongst the same large-scale structure of the Universe.  This endeavor led to advancements in our understanding of the CHIME telescope, astrophysical foreground removal, and the correlation of resulting maps with eBOSS galaxy survey maps.

A significant development emerged in the form of new foreground removal algorithms. Mapping the large-scale distribution of hydrogen on large scales is exceedingly difficult due to other bright sources of radio waves that contaminate our images. The new algorithm, integrating both linear and non-linear methods, effectively addressed the challenge of observing the cosmological hydrogen signal amidst bright astrophysical foregrounds. When tested in simulations, it demonstrated a noteworthy reduction in foreground residuals and showcased its capacity to recover the theoretical hydrogen signal under challenging conditions of observation, including imperfections in the telescope optics.

The cross-correlation analysis between the CHIME radio maps and the eBOSS galaxy catalogs yielded definitive statistical evidence for a detection of the large-scale structure of the Universe. This indicates that hydrogen gas does trace the same structure as galaxies, and provided insight about how the two tracers are related. This analysis constitutes the first detection of the large-scale structure using the CHIME telescope.

Expanding our analysis, we cross-correlated CHIME with yet another tracer of structure, the so-called Lyman-alpha forest. This measures the presence of matter through the absorption of light from distant galaxies by line-of-sight gas. Again, we made a definitive detection of the correlation signal. This constitutes the most-distant detection of large-scale structure using radio hydrogen maps.

The cumulative results of this collaborative effort lay the groundwork for future use of radio hydrogen maps to measure the large-scale structure of the Universe. Embedded in the detailed statistics of the large-scale structure is information about every aspect of the evolution of the Universe. As such, surveys of the structure can provide hints to questions such as: How did the Universe begin? How did it evolve to create the rich structure of galaxies, stars, and planets we see today? What is the fate of the Universe? Already, visible-light galaxy surveys like eBOSS are providing hints to these questions. However, radio telescopes are much more scalable, and should ultimately enable much larger surveys, with higher precision, and thus provide richer information. The work presented here is a milestone toward answering these fundamental questions about the Universe.
